item.title: Paralysed man with severed spine walks thanks to implant
item.description: World first using electrical implant developed by a team of Swiss researchers

item.title: Climate change: Top companies exaggerating their progress - study
item.description: Companies including Google, Amazon and Ikea are not meeting their own green targets, a report finds.

item.title: Fatherhood joy for paralysis implant dad
item.description: David Mâ€™zee received an electrical implant to his spine in 2017, it enables him to walk slowly and stand.

item.title: New greenfield housing still designed around cars, report finds
item.description: Services such as shops, schools and doctors are often almost impossible to reach on foot or by bike

item.title: Why switching asthma inhaler could be better for you and the planet
item.description: Aerosol asthma inhalers are cheap but not good for climate change - is there a better way for both patients and the planet?

item.title: Iceland whaling: Fisheries minister signals end from 2024
item.description: A fall in demand for Icelandic whale products means the controversial practice is no longer profitable.

item.title: Mount Everest: Mountain's highest glacier melting rapidly, new study shows
item.description: The melting is endangering both climbers and locals who rely on the glaciers for drinking water.

item.title: Parrots for sale: The internet's role in illicit trade
item.description: An investigation finds some 4,500 classified ads on social media, offering African grey parrots for sale.

item.title: Climate change threatening buried UK treasures
item.description: Our ability to understand Britain's history is at risk, warn archaeologists.

item.title: Toxic 'forever chemicals' found in British otters
item.description: Toxic chemicals used in non-stick saucepans are found in otters across England and Wales.

item.title: Climate change: 'Fragile win' at COP26 summit under threat
item.description: Alok Sharma warns that unless there's swift action this year, progress made at COP26 will be lost.

item.title: False banana: Is Ethiopia's enset 'wondercrop' for climate change?
item.description: The banana-like crop has the potential to feed more than 100 million people, according to research.

item.title: Giant pristine coral reef discovered off Tahiti
item.description: Marine explorers find a "pristine" 3km coral reef at depths of 30m off the coast of Tahiti.

item.title: Iris: Student-built robot rover on track to explore the Moon
item.description: A student-built rover is being prepared for a launch to the Moon later this year.

item.title: International Space Station to crash down to Earth in 2031
item.description: Nasa says the ISS will operate until 2030 before the agency hands over to commercial companies.

item.title: Elon Musk SpaceX rocket on collision course with moon
item.description: Astronomers say that a rocket in space since 2015 is hurtling towards the Moon where it will explode.

item.title: Radar satellite's stunning map of UK and Ireland
item.description: For some technologies there are never any clouds to spoil the view.

item.title: Shackleton's Endurance: The impossible search for the greatest shipwreck
item.description: The latest bid to find Antarctic explorer Ernest Shackleton's lost polar yacht is set to get under way.

item.title: Woolly mammoth and other Ice Age remains found in Devon
item.description: The bones, including those of a woolly rhinoceros and wolf, were found on a housing development.

item.title: What is the quantum apocalypse and should we be scared?
item.description: Security experts say a quantum computing leap could crack open all our secrets - so should we worry?

item.title: NIF: US lab takes further step towards nuclear fusion goal
item.description: US physicists confirm that they have achieved a stage in nuclear fusion called "burning plasma".

item.title: Winter Olympics: Will the Beijing Games be 'green and clean'?
item.description: China is promising a greener Winter Olympics, although critics are not sure if it can deliver.
